case_vignette:
A healthy 12-month-old infant girl presents with a yellowish-orange papule on the right upper extremity. Her mother first noticed this lesion approximately 6 months earlier. It has never bled, ulcerated, or formed blisters. The infant does not scratch the lesion nor appears otherwise bothered by it. However, when the lesion is rubbed, it appears to swell and turn bright red. On physical examination, there is a soft, oval-shaped, yellowish papule with a peripheral rim of erythema on the right extensor forearm. The infant's mother reports that the lesion has not changed in size or color over the past 6 months. The infant's mother is concerned that the lesion may be a sign of a serious underlying condition. The infant's mother is a 30-year-old woman who is otherwise healthy and has no significant medical history. The infant's father is a 35-year-old man who is also otherwise healthy and has no significant medical history. The infant's family history is unremarkable. The infant's mother reports that the infant has been breastfed since birth and has been taking a multivitamin supplement since 6 months of age. The infant's mother also reports that the infant has been exposed to the sun for short periods of time, but the lesion is not in a sun-exposed area. The infant's mother is concerned that the lesion may be a sign of a serious underlying condition. The infant's mother is worried that the lesion may be a sign of a serious underlying condition. The infant's mother is concerned that the lesion may be a sign of a serious underlying condition. The infant's mother is worried that the lesion may be a sign of a serious underlying condition.

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a yellowish-orange bump on my right upper arm that swells and turns bright red when rubbed, but it doesn't cause me any pain or discomfort.
How long have you had this bump on your arm?
I've had the bump on my arm for about 6 months.
Does the bump feel firm or soft, and is it fixed or mobile?
The bump feels soft.
Do you have similar bumps elsewhere on your body?
No, I do not have similar bumps elsewhere on my body.
Do you have any known allergies or have you been diagnosed with any skin conditions in the past?
No, I do not have any known allergies or diagnosed skin conditions.
Does anyone in your family have a history of skin diseases or similar symptoms?
No, my family history is unremarkable and does not include skin diseases or similar symptoms.
Final Diagnosis: Juvenile xanthogranuloma.
